entry.title: Lead in the Age of AI, Start with Your Data
entry.content:
At a Glance: Lead in the Age of AI, Start with Your Data  

AI is only as powerful as the data it runs on. Inaccurate context, broken semantics, or outdated master data can turn automation from an advantage into a riskâ€”costing companies millions each year in delays, errors, and lost trust.  

SAP Business Data Cloud provides a trusted data foundation by preserving semantics, logic, and context of enterprise data. This eliminates manual data work, accelerates decision-making, and enables CFOs, COOs, and CIOs to act on accurate, contextual data.

Leading companies are already replacing manual workarounds with reusable data products, harmonized KPIs, and automated reconciliations.  SAP Business Data Cloud is launching a hands-on webinar series to help organizations unleash speed, trust, and impact with their data.

Learn more:Getting Started Series: Experience SAP Business Data Cloud

Full article: Lead in the Age of AI, Start with Your Data

Imagine an AI that automatically optimizes pricing to clear inventory while protecting marginsâ€”without human input. Now imagine that AI running on inaccurate data: the wrong currency, outdated master data, or misaligned cost centers. Suddenly, automation isnâ€™t an advantageâ€”itâ€™s a risk. 

This is why data can no longer be treated as a back-office IT assetâ€”itâ€™s a strategic business capability. The companies leading in AI arenâ€™t the ones with the most data, but the ones with the right data, at the right time, with the right context. 

When Poor Data Foundations Impact the Bottom Line  

According to Forrester, poor data quality costs organizations over $5 million annually. Even more alarming, 7% report losses of $25 million or more (Forrester, 2024). Gartner research reinforces this reality.  In a 2020 study, Gartner found that poor data quality costs organizations an average of $12.9 million annually (Gartner 2020).  

Itâ€™s rarely the volume of data that slows organizations downâ€”itâ€™s the lack of business context. Poorly managed master data, disconnected hierarchies, missing lineage, and duplicated logic all contribute to fragmented views that undermine trust, delay decisions, and increase cost. 

The typical workaround? Manual fixes: recreating data context, writing custom scripts, and rebuilding SAPâ€™s logic in other tools. These solutions are often fragile, expensive, manual and error prone. When systems change or org structures realign, the fixes can breakâ€”and IT has a new project all over again. 

The result: every decision takes longer, and every delay carries a cost. 

The consequences are real: 

  • Product profitability becomes unreliable if cost and pricing data use different hierarchies 
  • Regional forecasting fails when customer hierarchies are inconsistent 
  • KPIs vary between teams because each is working with different assumptions 

The impact on business leaders: 

  • CFOs risk inaccurate forecasts, delayed closes, and loss in profits 
  • COOs waste time waiting on reconciling reports instead of driving execution 
  • CIOs / CDOs see mounting costs as teams duplicate work, rebuild logic, and rely on shadow systems 

Leading companies are changing courseâ€”not by rebuilding data outside SAP, but by activating the trusted business logic already in place. 

Unleash Speed, Trust, and Impact with SAP Business Data Cloud  

SAP Business Data Cloud helps organizations turn fragmented data into a trusted foundation for decision-making. By unifying data across systems and preserving the business context that gives it meaning it significantly reduces the need for manual reconciliation or reengineering.  

The result is now reversed because the data is accurate, and actionable, enabling faster execution, stronger alignment, and higher return on data investments. 

How SAP Business Data Cloud strengthens enterprise data foundations: 

  • Preserve context natively: context, semantics, logic, and hierarchies stay intactâ€”no rework needed. 
  • Deliver trusted, reusable data products: Instead of manually preparing data for every model or report, teams can access governed, curated assets that reflect real business truth. 
  • Empower intelligent applications: With high-quality, harmonized data at their core, applications for planning, forecasting, sustainability, and operations drive insights where decisions happen real timeâ€”not after the fact. 

Customer Transformation in Action 
Discover how leading organizations are transforming their business with trusted data. Hereâ€™s a collection of customer testimonials showcasing how SAP helps companies tackle opportunities across industriesâ€”whether through modernization, real-time decision-making, or unlocking new growth powered by SAP Business Data Cloud. 

SAP Featured Stories for Business Data Cloud 

Experience SAP Business Data Cloud First-Hand:
To experience the power of SAP Business Data Cloud, join a hands-on webinar series designed to accelerate data strategies. Across a series of interactive modules, here SAPâ€™s product and leadership teams guide participants through practical steps to unlock business value from their data.  

Topics include:  

  • Build and simulate outcomes with Intelligent Applications 
  • Accelerate AI innovation with SAP Databricks 
  • Create analytical models and data products in SAP Datasphere

Learn directly from some of the industry experts on how to turn data into a true business driver.

Learn more: Getting Started Series: Experience SAP Business Data Cloud

entry.title: DSP SQL Navigator â€“ Stop copy pasting URLs!
entry.content:
I have been working with SAP Datasphere since 2019, back when it was still called SAP Data Warehouse Cloud (DWC). Obviously I have built my fair share of SQL views, and have been analyzing SQL views even more. That means a lot of jumping from one SQL view to another, which I do through copy-pasting the URL that I am currently on and changing it to the view I want to jump to. I must have copy-pasted hours on end since 2019 on a daily basis. But that is now behind me, and I will make sure you donâ€™t have to anymore as well!

So like I wrote in the introduction, what I do to jump from one SQL view, to the view that lies beneath it is:

  • Copy the current URL
  • Copy the view name I want to jump into
  • Overwrite the last part of the URL with this view name.

I have always thought there must be a faster way to do this. With the upcoming of â€œvibe-codingâ€ and tools like Cursor and Claude Code, I finally tried to make my day a lot easier, by trying to code a browser extension.

Together with Claude I wrote a Product Requirement Document (PRD) and started working on the project together with Claude Code. Within a few hours the first useful version of the browser extension could be imported into my browser, and just a few hours later I had a polished version that I am now ready to share with you!

The plugin basically automated my old workflow. When you are in a SQL view and want to jump to the SQL view underneath that one, you simply select the view you want to jump to and press your hotkey and it open a new browser tab and open up that view for you!

Want to try it out? Basically all you have to do is download the plugin browser from the Google Web Store through this link. Then you have to assign a hotkey via the settings of the plugin and it works! You can also first check the demo if you want in this Youtube movie, where I show off the process! 

I am currently still working on the feature to jump to a view that is shared from another space, and will bring a new version of the plugin as soon as possible. If you have any questions please feel free to reach out to me!

entry.title: End-to-End Business Transformation with SAP AI Tools: A Practical Example
entry.content:
About Me

Hare Krishna ğŸ™ I am an SAP BTP Cloud Architect sharing practical insights, solutions, and real-world experiences from the SAP ecosystem.

Introduction: Simplifying Grocery Business with AI ğŸ¥¦ğŸ›’

Grocery businesses handling food items and eatables want to deliver products faster, reduce mistakes, and delight customers. SAP offers a suite of AI tools that can automate, predict, and optimize business processes. In this example, weâ€™ll show how a large grocery chain can transform its Order-to-Cash (O2C) processâ€”from receiving orders to delivering products and receiving paymentsâ€”using SAP AI tools.

Note: O2C is the flow where a customer places an order, the company delivers the product, and receives payment.

1. Organizing Data with SAP Datasphere ğŸ¢ğŸ’¾ğŸ“Š

Objective: Combine data from sales, inventory, shipments, and suppliers into one view.

How it works:

  • Connect SAP systems and external sources (like supply chain partners and e-commerce platforms) ğŸ”—.

  • Transform raw data into business-friendly models for orders, deliveries, and payments ğŸ—‚ï¸.

Benefit for growth:
A grocery chain can reduce stock-outs and overstock ğŸ“‰, understand customer buying patterns ğŸ›ï¸, and ensure timely deliveries ğŸšš. With a single source of truth, managers make faster and more informed decisions ğŸ§ .

Analogy: Central nervous system â€“ integrates and harmonizes all data from multiple sources.

2. Managing AI Services with SAP AI Foundation âš™ï¸ğŸ› ï¸ğŸ“ˆ

Objective: Provide infrastructure and services to deploy, monitor, and orchestrate AI models efficiently.

How it works:

  • SAP AI Foundation handles model orchestration, monitoring, logging, and deployment pipelines ğŸ–¥ï¸.

  • Works seamlessly with AI Core, ML DI tenants, and other AI services ğŸ”„.

Benefit for growth:
The grocery chain can scale AI solutions reliably âš¡, ensuring smooth operations across multiple stores and warehouses ğŸ¬ without disruptions. Managers can monitor model performance in real-time ğŸ•µï¸, improving efficiency and reducing costs ğŸ’°.

Analogy: AI control center â€“ orchestrates and monitors AI models and workflows.

3. Predicting Outcomes with SAP AI Core & ML DI Tenants ğŸ¤–ğŸ“¡ğŸ”®

Objective: Predict delivery delays, demand spikes, or payment issues.

How it works:

  • Build predictive models in SAP AI Core ğŸ§©.

  • Use ML DI tenants to access pre-trained AI models or train new ones using integrated data from SAP Datasphere ğŸ—„ï¸.

Benefit for growth:
The grocery chain can anticipate high-demand periods ğŸ“ˆ, avoid perishable food wastage ğŸ¥¬âŒ, and ensure timely replenishment ğŸš›. Predictive insights also help in identifying potential payment delays ğŸ’³ or customer churn ğŸ”„, boosting revenue and trust.

Analogy: Predictive brain â€“ builds and deploys AI models for forecasting and insights.

4. Automating Tasks with SAP Build Process Automation ğŸ”„ğŸ¤–ğŸ“

Objective: Reduce manual work and speed up processes.

How it works:

  • Automate routine O2C tasks like approving orders âœ…, sending invoices ğŸ§¾, and following up on payments ğŸ“¬.

  • Integrate AI predictions to trigger actions automatically âš¡.

Benefit for growth:
The grocery chain can process orders faster â±ï¸, minimize human errors âŒ, and focus staff on higher-value tasks ğŸ’¼. Automation ensures smoother operations and higher customer satisfaction ğŸ˜ƒ.

Analogy: Workflow robot â€“ automates repetitive tasks and business processes.

5. Guiding Employees with SAP Joule ğŸ’¡ğŸ“ŒğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’¼

Objective: Provide real-time insights and recommendations.

How it works:

  • SAP Joule offers suggestions, such as which deliveries might be delayed â³ or which customers need follow-up ğŸ“.

  • Employees can take immediate, informed actions ğŸƒâ€â™‚ï¸.

Benefit for growth:
Employees make smarter decisions faster âš¡, improving delivery efficiency ğŸšš, customer loyalty â¤ï¸, and operational agility ğŸ¬. Real-time guidance reduces mistakes and accelerates response times â±ï¸.

Analogy: Smart advisor â€“ gives insights in real-time.

6. Integrating Security & Identity with SAP BTP IAS/IPS ğŸ”’ğŸ›¡ï¸ğŸ”‘

Objective: Secure AI and process automation tools while ensuring correct user access.

How it works:

  • IAS manages Single Sign-On (SSO) ğŸ” for employees interacting with SAP AI tools.

  • IPS ensures only authorized users are provisioned into the system ğŸ‘¤.

Benefit for growth:
The grocery chain protects sensitive customer and supplier data ğŸ—‚ï¸, ensures compliance ğŸ“‹, and safely enables access to AI tools across multiple locations ğŸŒ.

Analogy: Security gatekeeper â€“ ensures authorized access to AI tools & data.

7. Monitoring & Continuous Improvement with SAP Cloud ALM ğŸ“ŠğŸ–¥ï¸âš¡

Objective: Ensure the system works well and keeps improving.

How it works:

  • Track AI model performance and automated workflows using SAP Cloud ALM ğŸ“ˆ.

  • Use feedback and metrics to refine AI models and automations ğŸ”„.

Benefit for growth:
The grocery chain can continuously improve operations ğŸ¬, adapt to market changes ğŸ”„, and maintain high customer satisfaction ğŸ˜ƒ. Monitoring helps spot inefficiencies before they affect operations âš ï¸.

Analogy: System monitor â€“ tracks performance & supports continuous improvement.

8. Enabling Real-Time Events with SAP Event Mesh ğŸŒâš¡

Objective: Ensure real-time communication between systems and trigger actions instantly across the O2C process.

How it works:

  • SAP Event Mesh enables event-driven messaging, connecting orders, inventory updates, delivery notifications, and payment confirmations.

  • Works seamlessly with SAP Build Process Automation and AI predictions to trigger automated workflows immediately.

Benefit for growth:
The grocery chain can respond instantly to order changes, prevent stockouts, and ensure customers get accurate delivery updates ğŸššğŸ“². Real-time events also help coordinate multiple stores and warehouses efficiently ğŸ¬, improving overall operational agility.

Analogy: Real-time traffic controller â€“ directs information instantly to where itâ€™s needed, keeping the flow smooth.

9. Business Insights with SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) ğŸ“ŠğŸ’¡

Objective: Turn all collected data and AI predictions into actionable dashboards and reports.

How it works:

  • SAC connects to SAP Datasphere and AI Core models to provide interactive dashboards, forecasts, and KPI tracking.

  • Managers and executives can visualize order trends, inventory levels, and delivery performance in real-time.

Benefit for growth:
The grocery chain can make data-driven strategic decisions, optimize promotions, plan inventory better, and track overall performance ğŸ“ˆ. This strengthens customer satisfaction and profitability.

Analogy: Digital dashboard â€“ shows the full picture at a glance for informed decisions.

Industry Example / Use Case Snapshot ğŸ¥¬ğŸ“¦

Scenario: A grocery chain receives an online order for fresh produce, including perishable vegetables and fruits.

End-to-End Flow Using SAP Tools:

  1. Data Integration (SAP Datasphere ğŸ¢ğŸ’¾)

    • The order details, inventory levels, and supplier availability are immediately centralized.

  2. Predictive Insights (SAP AI Core & ML DI ğŸ¤–)

    • AI predicts potential delivery delays due to traffic or stock shortages and estimates optimal delivery routes.

  3. Automation (SAP Build Process Automation ğŸ”„ğŸ¤–)

    • The system automatically confirms the order, checks stock, and triggers procurement if needed.

  4. Real-Time Events (SAP Event Mesh ğŸŒâš¡)

    • Updates on stock, delivery status, and payment confirmations are shared instantly across all systems.

  5. Employee Guidance (SAP Joule ğŸ’¡ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’¼)

    • Warehouse staff receive recommendations on packing priorities for perishable items to minimize spoilage.

  6. Analytics & Reporting (SAC ğŸ“ŠğŸ’¡)

    • Managers monitor order fulfillment KPIs, customer satisfaction, and stock movement in dashboards.

  7. Monitoring & Continuous Improvement (Cloud ALM ğŸ“Šâš¡)

    • Performance metrics from this order feed into ongoing AI model tuning and process optimization.

Outcome:

  • The perishable order is delivered fresh, on time, and with minimal wastage.

  • Employees work efficiently guided by AI insights.

  • Managers gain actionable insights, helping the grocery chain increase customer satisfaction and reduce losses.

Key Takeaways âœ…

  • Streamlined Operations ğŸ¢ğŸ¤–: SAP tools optimize the entire Order-to-Cash workflow.

  • Smart Decisions ğŸ’¡ğŸ“Š: AI predictions and dashboards support faster, data-driven choices.

  • Automation & Real-Time âš¡ğŸ”„: Workflows run instantly with minimal manual effort.

  • Guided Workforce ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’¼ğŸ’¡: Employees get actionable insights in real time.

  • Secure & Monitored ğŸ”’ğŸ“Š: Access is controlled and performance continuously tracked.

  • Customer Satisfaction ğŸššâ¤ï¸: Faster fulfillment, fewer errors, and smarter operations boost growth.

Ask & Learn ğŸ¤”

Q1: What is Order-to-Cash (O2C)?
Itâ€™s the process of taking a customer order, delivering the product, and receiving payment.

Q2: Do I need technical skills to use these SAP AI tools?
No. Tools like SAP Joule and SAC provide simple insights and dashboards that non-technical employees can use.

Q3: How does SAP Event Mesh help in this workflow?
Event Mesh enables real-time messaging between systems, triggering automated workflows instantly for faster operations.

Q4: Can automation replace employees?
Automation handles repetitive tasks, allowing employees to focus on higher-value work and make smarter decisions with AI guidance.

Q5: How does SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) add value?
SAC converts data and AI predictions into dashboards and KPIs, enabling strategic and operational decisions.

Q6: How is data security ensured?
SAP BTP IAS/IPS manages user authentication and provisioning, ensuring only authorized access to AI tools and sensitive data.

Q7: How do I measure improvement?
SAP Cloud ALM tracks system performance, AI model effectiveness, and workflow efficiency for continuous improvement.

entry.title: Release Navigator for SAP BTP - What's New in Q3 2025
entry.content:
The Release Navigator for SAP BTP continues to evolve and expand, offering our customers improved resources and streamlined access to product updates.

With the Q3 2025 update, we ensured all content is up-to-date and we are excited to announce the addition of a new product page for SAP Customer Data Solutions as well as some cosmetic UI updates. Read more about the details in this blog post.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Collaborating closely with SAP BTP experts, we've expanded the release coverage by introducing 11 new product pages. These pages compile links to all available release information, such as schedules, pre- and post-release communications, blogs, and more:

  • SAP Customer Data Solutions, including
    • SAP Customer Data Cloud / SAP Customer Identity and Access Management
    • SAP Customer Data Platform

Read on to see what you can find on this new page.

SAP Customer Data Solutions

This page contains specific resources for SAP Customer Identity and Access Management, SAP Customer Data Platform, as well as release resources relevant across different SAP Customer Data Solutions. Hereâ€™s a list of all you can find on this page:

  • SAP Customer Identity and Access Management (CDC)
    • Roadmap Explorer: Upcoming Innovations
    • Whatâ€™s New Viewer: Release Notes
    • Customer Influence Campaign
    • SAP Community Tag
  • SAP Customer Data Platform
    • Roadmap Explorer: Upcoming Innovations
    • Whatâ€™s New Viewer: Release Notes
    • Customer Influence Campaign
    • SAP Community Tag
  • General Customer Data Solutions Resources
    • SAP BTP Newsletter
    • Enablement Webcasts
    • Subscription link to Cloud Availability Center

Please Note: This page has previously been available via the Release Navigator for Customer Experience. Adding this page to the Release Navigator for SAP BTP reflects the move of SAP Customer Data Solutions from the Customer Experience area to SAP BTP. The page in the Release Navigator for Customer Experience will stay online until the beginning of Q4 2025 for everyone to take note and switch out their potential bookmarks or saved links. After that, only the page within the Release Navigator for SAP BTP will remain available.

Check it out.

 

 

With this last round of updates, we added new visual elements to all release navigators. The UI updates in the Release Navigator for SAP BTP do not affect functionality or performance and are strictly cosmetical.

On the home page also known as the Product Specific page, you will notice that our Welcome and Release Calendar cards have received a facelift for a fresher look and feel. 

On all pages where you can open informational text boxes by hovering over the lightbulb icon, you will see a slight update to the design of these boxes. Content and functionality remain the same. 

As a reminder: These pop-up boxes show up on every page with a lightbulb icon at the top and may be moved around on the page or closed once you are done reading them.

 

 

For centralized information regarding the release of new features for SAP BTP products and services, consult the Consolidated Release Schedule for SAP BTP.

Regarding the Release Navigator updates, refer to this update plan:

*Disclaimer: The schedule is subject to alterations without notice, including potential delays or the integration of changes in subsequent update windows. It doesn't establish a commitment, promise, or legal duty to deliver any material, code, or functionality. Looking into the remaining quarters of 2025, updates will focus on quarterly content maintenance and a steady extension of product coverage. No substantial UI updates are planned for the time being.

 

 

The Readiness@Scale team within SAP Enterprise Support is driven to ensure release readiness across the SAP Enterprise Support portfolio. Our mission is to empower SAP customers to effectively adopt and utilize innovations.

If you have feedback or specific requests for content within the release navigator, feel free to contact us.

Don't forget to explore our teamâ€™s blogs tagged under Readiness@Scale.

Happy navigating!

Readiness@Scale  
SAP Enterprise Support

entry.title: UPDATE: SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud Availability via SAP Business Data Cloud
entry.content:
After the announcement on July 1st regarding the availability of SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud (public option) via SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC), the reaction was of great excitement and interest in learning more about the next steps especially about the tenant rewiring option to move existing tenants to SAP BDC. If you missed the announcement, you could read it here: Announcement: SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud - SAP Community

The objective of this blog is to share with you the latest information about the tenant rewiring and what it involves.

First, what does it mean for an SAP Datasphere or SAP Analytics Cloud to be rewired?

A tenant rewiring does not mean artefacts or data migration, it mainly refers to the consumption approach (from a commercial model perspective) of these services, and to the customer facing tool to manage the tenant lifecycles (via SAP for Me).  The tenant itself will remain the same, and the URL of the current tenants will not change either. In addition, there are no additional charges for rewiring an SAP Datasphere or SAP Analytics Cloud tenant to SAP BDC.

Second, how will the tenant rewiring work?

There are two paths for customers when it comes to how the tenant rewiring will work.

Customers may have started their consumption of SAP Datasphere or SAP Analytics Cloud (public option) via one of the following consumption models:

  • A subscription of the services where the tenants are provisioned and managed by SAP
  • A subscription of the services where the tenants are provisioned self-service by customers via the customers SAP BTP Global Accounts.

The tenant rewiring tool will support both models; however, the way the process is triggered will be different.

For the SAP-managed / provisioned tenants, the tenant rewiring will be initiated automatically as soon as you update your subscription with SAP (via your SAP account team) to move your subscription from the standalone product subscription to the SAP BDC subscription. This means that the tenant rewiring will be initiated as part of your subscription change request, and the tenant will automatically move to SAP BDC.

When you have a new subscription to SAP BDC, you will receive an email notification from SAP to log into your SAP for Me account. You will need to activate your BDC cockpit in your appropriate data center. If these steps are done prior to the tenant rewiring process, you will be able to see the rewired tenants in your BDC formation as soon as the process is completed.

NOTE: You must use the same hyperscaler and the same data center for your BDC cockpit as your current standalone subscription. The tenant rewiring tool does not migrate tenants between hyperscalers or data centers.

It is important to mention that the tenant will be available for your end users during the process and there is no tenant downtime required by the tenant rewiring tool.

For the tenants that are provisioned self-service via the customers SAP BTP Global Account, your admin will be able to initiate the tenant rewiring directly via the BTP Global Account, also self-service. The only pre-condition required is that a BDC subscription must pre-exist before triggering the tenant rewiring process to move the tenant to SAP BDC.

The steps are as follows:

  • BTP Admin goes in the BTP Global Account / BTP cockpit and updates the BTP Service instance related to the tenant
  • The request is received by SAP and the process is initiated to update the tenant and move it to BDC
  • Login to SAP for Me and, login to BDC, go to the resources tab where you will be able to find the rewired tenants under â€œbdc-rewiredâ€ resource group.
  • Once the rewiring is completed, the tenant will be visible in BDC

Overall, the tenants are preserved and now will be consumed via SAP BDC.

For more information and step-by-step, visit the tenant rewiring documentation.

SAP Analytics Cloud in this blog refers to the following:

  • SAP Analytics Cloud for business intelligence, public system option
  • SAP Analytics Cloud for planning, standard edition, public system option
  • SAP Analytics Cloud for planning, professional edition, public system option
  • SAP Analytics Cloud, test tenant, public system option

entry.title: SAP Datasphere - Architecture and Lessons-Learned
entry.content:
The open nature of SAP Datasphere's architecture is very much like Sergio Leone's epic spaghetti Western film, "The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly" for no reason other than how some designs can be described as such.

One of Datasphereâ€™s biggest strength is the flexibility in how quickly a new solution can be built. It is delightfully fast. From the initial replication of SAP tables to a consumption-ready Analytical model, the development time is a fraction of prior efforts. Unfortunately, this same speed when unsupervised can lead to an excessive number of objects that will clutter and ironically slow down development.

Issues with Runaway Spaces

  • Production models using Development data
  • Transports of objects between spaces break
  • Navigation and development become a chore

If you're considering SAP Datasphere as a BW replacement or if you're already kicking the tires with a pilot project, this will help (and save you months of rework).

After implementing SAP Datasphere for a couple of clients, I've encountered limitations of the common, initial setup (The Bad) and worked through the growing pains of architecture the landscape to a scalable design that accommodates multiple teams and lines of business (The Good).

The First Design â€“ Our Initial Approach

  • 1-tenant
  • 1-space per environment

An initial design may look like this, which isn't all that bad (but there is a better approach that I will explain later).

It is simple concept to understand. The development objects are drafted in a Development space (DEV). The refined objects are imported and tested in a Quality Assurance space (QA). The approved objects are reviewed and imported into a Production space (PRD).

This approach isolates the objects based on their maturity along the development, testing, and approval process. It also helps the technical team as they explore SAP Datasphere concepts, such as graphical versus SQL views, relational vs. fact, dataflow vs replication flow, and so forth. It's a good start.

 

The First Issues

We started running into trouble, however, during promotion or "transports" of objects.

Because each space was a different database schema, we had to take care when exporting the CSN file that contained our object definition, which required manually editing the database prefix via a text editor before importing it into the next space.

We had edit access to the three spaces, so sometimes we find an object in the Quality Assurance or Production space may be referring an object from the Development space.

This issue was compounded as our team grew and required additional coordination.

  • How can we ensure business analysts do not change IT-developed objects?
  • How do we define security so that only the approved personnel can view sensitive information?
  • Is everyone following the same approach for development, testing (quality assurance), and production?

Our SAP Datasphere architecture had to adapt and service the growing IT team and the addition of new business groups. The number of mistakes increased as the teams grew. We had to find another way.

 

The Revision

The Second Design â€“ Our Revision

  • 2-tenants (PRD and DEV/QA)
  • 1 inbound-space
  • 1 modeling-space

Our second design of the Datasphere architecture separated the initial, inbound tables into its own space.

This allowed use to refine the role of the modelers, separating the ones who were developing the master data dimensions and relational datasets apart from those who had additional access to maintain system connections and monitor data flows and tasks chains. This was an IT-centric approach because we were on boarding more data engineers to help with the workload while defining roles and responsibilities.

With the second SAP Datasphere tenant, the transport process was smoother since we no longer had to manually edit CSN files. Also, the concern about mixing Production and Development objects were gone because the objects were in different tenants.

I imagine most teams stop here and this approach works well for IT-centric organizations where the data engineers are responsible for most of the data modeling. This approach also allows the larger group of data engineers to focus on building the data models while a smaller group maintain and coordinate the data loads as not overwhelm the environment.

 

The Final Architecture

The Third Design â€“ Our Current Architecture

  • 3-tenants (PRD, QA, and DEV)
  • 1 inbound-space
  • 1 modeling-space
  • 1 admin-space
  • n business-space

Our third design of the SAP Datasphere architecture grew out of the initial success of our reporting and data project.

The business teams were excited with their new dashboards and the speed in which our team were able to deliver new models. The demand from our business community exceeded our team's ability to deliver due to the volume of the requests. Around this time, there was a concern about data sensitivity especially around the company financial information.

The admin-space allowed use to define row-level security via Data Access Controls (DAC). Once defined, these objects can be shared to the modeling-space. Very few people on the team were granted access to maintain objects in the admin-space.

The modeling-space remains largely the same. The data engineers continued to build their initial propagation views and fact views, maintaining the relationships and semantic enrichment. What changed was the omission of analytical models.

When ready, the fact views were shared to the business-specific spaces. This allowed the business analysis to further refine the models for their specific needs, such as adding custom restrictive measures, calculations, or aggregations.

This 3-layered approach (inbound, modeling, and reporting) allowed the data engineers who are familiar with the source SAP table relationships to build a strong foundation in the modeling-space while allowing the business analysis to consume and tailor the output.

 

Next Time

If I were to build another SAP Datasphere tenant from the ground-up, I would keep the spaces to a minimum but allow the tenant to expand with the growing pains (of rearchitecting). In essence, it would be a slimmed version of the third design.

The Space Template

  • 2-tenant (minimum), 3-tenant (recommended)
  • 1 inbound-space
  • 1 modeling-space
  • 1 reporting-space

Now that SAP Datasphere (formerly Data Warehouse Cloud and recently packaged under SAP Business Data Cloud) has been released and used by customers for a several years now, Iâ€™m curious to hear how itâ€™s been deployed. How are you organizing the Spaces (by domain, team, or lifecycle)? Who owns the metric definitions across Spaces? How do you package the Datasphere models so that the SAC teams can consume them easily?

entry.title: SAP Datasphere News in August
entry.content:
SAP Datasphere News in August

Another month with two nice new release deliveries âœ¨

Learn more in my short top features video in August 2025 on YouTube ğŸ“º

In addition, explore the latest updates in our community news blogs and more.

 

 

My top features in August

 

Transformation Flow: Processing in Batches

You can now break down large transformation flow datasets into batches to avoid out-of-memory (OOM) errors when using the SAP HANA runtime in Datasphere. Defining batches on transformation flows enhances the performance and reliability, while ensuring efficient data integration and processing.

You find this feature in the data integration monitor as it is part of the runtime settings under the Batches tab. Simply pick a suitable column and define the batch sizes in number or records. You can also define to use it only for a large initial load or both initial and delta loads.

â¡ï¸  More information.

 

New source and targets for Replication Flows

Microsoft OneLake as a Source for Your Replication Flow

You can now use Microsoft OneLakeâ€”which was formerly also known as Azure Data Lake Generation 2â€”, and the corresponding connection type to add sources to replication flows and replicate data in CSV format from the source for initial loads.

â¡ï¸  More information.

  • Cloud Storage Provider Sources
  • Microsoft OneLake Connections

 

SAP Signavio as Target for Your Replication Flows

You can now use connection type SAP Signavio and replication flows to load data from SAP source systems, such as SAP S/4HANA and others, into SAP Signavio as target system. This allows an efficient and scalable data replication into the SAP Signavio solution.

â¡ï¸  More information.

  • SAP Signavio Targets
  • SAP Signavio Connections

 

SAP Analytics Cloud, add-in for Microsoft Excel

There is a very nice feature new in SAP Analytics Cloud, which I think is super useful for many of you. With the QRC 3 release, you can transfer a table from an SAC story to Excel and further use it with the add-in. In Excel, the transferred table is based on the same data source, for example Datasphere, and has the same navigation state (dimensions, measures in rows and columns, filters, and variables). The idea is to benefit from native Excel capabilities on Datasphere data in real time. You can adjust the report, add custom functions on top of the table, and more.

â¡ï¸  More information.

 



SAP Business Data Cloud Getting Started Series

 

Starting September 10, the Getting Started Series kicks off with three modules

  • Module 1: Build an Intelligent Application Grounded in Data Products (Sep 10, 2025)
  • Module 2: Fuel AI Innovation with SAP Databricks in Business Data Cloud (Sep 24, 2025)
  • Module 3: Create and Enrich an Analytical Model with SAP Datasphere (Oct 8, 2025)

ğŸ‘‰  Sign up today on the registration page.

â¡ï¸  Step-By-Step Guide: Getting started with the SAP Business Data Cloud Basic Trial

 

Learning Update

Our learning colleagues are currently defining a brand new course: Becoming an SAP Data Architect.

You will learn:

ğŸ”¹How Data Architecture enables efficiency, innovation, and measurable business outcomes

ğŸ”¹ Ways to communicate complex data concepts clearly â€” to both technical and non-technical stakeholders

ğŸ”¹ How to identify and prioritize opportunities, build business cases, and articulate value

ğŸ”¹ Techniques for designing target-state architectures aligned with SAP Business Data Cloud, SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP Datasphere

ğŸ”¹ Storytelling methods to overcome resistance and foster adoption of data-driven change

 

This course is the first step in a learning path:

âœ…  Start with the free â€œBecoming an SAP Data Architectâ€ course in November 2025

âœ…  Continue with a free advanced course coming early 2026

ğŸ†  Together, they prepare you for a brand-new SAP Data Architect certification in 2026

 

My favorite blogs in August

 

Use SAP Business Data Cloud Capacity Estimator

There is a great blog series about the capacity estimator SAP Business Data Cloud, which of course also includes the SAP Datasphere estimator by @FernandaFroelich. Not all blogs are published yet as the series is work in progress, but already a great start:

  1. Learn How to use SAP Business Data Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator?
  2. Explore How to edit a quota assignment in SAP Business Data Cloud?
  3. Use the Capacity Unit Estimator across SAP Analytics Cloud, SAP Datasphere, and SAP Databricks. 

 

SAP Business Data Cloud rewiring of existing Datasphere and SAC tenants

My dear colleague @Ammar_Naji has updated his blog on the rewiring option for existing SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud tenants. Very informative and includes all the steps which need to be done.

â¡ï¸  UPDATE: SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud Availability via SAP Business Data Cloud

 

Open Resource Directory

This is a must read for all SAP Business Data Cloud experts out there:
â¡ï¸  Why we created Open Resource Discovery

The Open Resource Discovery (ORD) is the core protocol for application / service metadata publishing and discovery within SAP Business Data Cloud. This blog written by @SimonHeimler explains the concepts behind the scenes and gives you links to resources where you find further details.

 

SAP Datasphere SQL Navigator browser plugin

SAP Mentor and active community member @kostertim has created a very useful browser plugin to be able to navigate from one SQL view to another by just highlighting the view and using a hotkey combination or browser context menuâ€”avoiding a lot of copy-and-paste efforts. All is described in his blog â¡ï¸  DSP SQL Navigator â€“ Stop copy pasting URLs! And of course the YouTube video:

entry.title: Restrict Access of OAuth2.0 Clients with the Technical User purpose
entry.content:
Hi,

New updates keep arriving our way, let's review one of the latest and compare with the previous situation.  The feature I'm talking about is the new purpose for OAuth2.0 Clients, named the 'Technical user'. 

 

What's new about it?

The Technical User purpose allows you to create OAuth 2.0 clients that can be linked to all scoped roles within your SAP Datasphere tenant. This includes:

  • General roles at the tenant level
  • and/or Roles at the space level

By leveraging this setup, you can enforce granular access restrictions. This means you can precisely control what the technical user can access, ensuring compliance with security and governance requirements.

Let's compare the purposes side-by-side


Interactive UsageFor human users who log in interactively via OAuth. Requires re-authorization based on Refresh Token Lifetime. - Logging into the Command Line Interface (CLI)
- Consuming data via OData API		 
API AccessFor programmatic access to APIs, typically for integrations.- Using SCIM 2.0 API for user provisioning
- Transporting content via Cloud Transport Management
- Exporting logs (audit activities)
- Connecting SAP Signavio		Limited to API-level permissions (tenant wide however)
Technical UserFor system-to-system communication or automation without user interaction.- Same as API Access but with broader flexibility
- Can include tenant-level and space-level roles
- Ideal for background jobs, ETL processes, and automation		Can be linked to all scoped roles (tenant + space)

 

 

In short we can conclude the following:

  • Interactive Usage: Used for CLI & OData API's. Provide the client parameters to users who need to connect clients, tools, or apps to SAP Datasphere
  • API Access: Designed for API calls (SCIM 2.0 API's, transporting content) but role assignment is limited.
  • Technical User: Same as API Access  but offers full role assignment flexibility, making it the most powerful for automation and service accounts.

You can read how to use OAuth2.0 Clients to Authenticate against SAP Datasphere for yourself here:  https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_DATASPHERE/9f804b8efa8043539289f42f372c4862/3f92b46fe0314e8ba60720e409c219fc.html. And thanks for reading the blog! Hope you share your own experience with the purposes in the comment section.

Kind Regards, Thibault
